page.title: 01INTRODUCTION TO GLENLUCE
page.content: This area has attracted settlers since the end of the {Ice Age}(8000 BC) Neolithiic hunters 4000 years ago built the world's oldest pitfall trap in Luce Bay. In 1192{Cistercians}built Glenluce Abbey in rich valley of River Luce. Today {climate and soil}support thriving agriculture,including beef, sheep, dairy, pig and arable farming. The tenanted farms mostly belong to the Earl of Stair. Rural beauty is unspoiled by industrial development, and public rights of way abound. Rare species of{flora}are found in peat bogs and acid dunes; coniferous forests provide a habitat for wild deer; migrating ducks, geese and swans visit annually. Luce Water is famous for salmon, and the picturesque viaduct over the river remains a monument to the{rail-link}closed in 1965.
